text: Unreachable code is a section of code in a program that can never be executed. Having unreachable code is bad because it wastes space on the disk, memory, and CPU cache. Luckily, many modern compilers alert the programmer with a warning or error whenever it detects unreachable code. == Example == void beepForever() { while (true) { System.out.println("Beep!"); } System.out.println(":'("); } In this example, `":'("` will never be printed because the loop never exits. Category:Computer programming == References ==
title: Unreachable code
